question: Are Cryptanthus and Gagea, both a genus?

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about the genus Cryptanthus.
nodes.output: The genus Cryptanthus is a part of the Bromeliaceae family, with all species being endemic to Brazil. The genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Hoplocryptanthus". The common name for any Cryptanthus is "Earth Star". Some species within this genus include Cryptanthus regius, Cryptanthus sanctaluciae, Cryptanthus tiradentesensis, Cryptanthus warasii, and Cryptanthus warren-loosei, all of which are also endemic to Brazil.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about the genus Gagea.
nodes.output: Gagea is a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family, primarily found in Eurasia with a few species extending into North Africa and North America. It is also worth noting that the genus was historically considered to be part of the tribe Lloydieae, but in 2013, it was proposed to be split off from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae. This information provides an overview of the genus Gagea and its classification within the plant kingdom.

nodes.instruction: Determine if Cryptanthus is classified as a genus based on the retrieved information.
nodes.output: Based on the information provided, Cryptanthus is classified as a genus within the Bromeliaceae family.

nodes.instruction: Determine if Gagea is classified as a genus based on the retrieved information.
nodes.output: Based on the retrieved information, Gagea is classified as a genus within the plant kingdom.

nodes.instruction: Based on the classifications from nodes 3 and 4, determine if both Cryptanthus and Gagea are genera.
nodes.output: Yes, both Cryptanthus and Gagea are genera. Cryptanthus is a genus within the Bromeliaceae family, and Gagea is a genus within the plant kingdom.

retrieved_passages:
Cryptanthus
Cryptanthus is a genus in the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. The genus name is from the Greek “cryptos” (hidden) and “anthos” (flower). This genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Hoplocryptanthus" . All species of this genus are endemic to Brazil. The common name for any "Cryptanthus" is "Earth Star".

Grace After Midnight
According to the memoir, Pearson says her life was turned around upon learning in prison that a close friend and drug dealer, whom she called "Uncle", was killed. Pearson said of her decision to write her book, "I just want to let people know where I came from ... to share my story. I know the Lord has blessed me. He gave me the power just to tell this story." The book also depicts the difficulty with which Pearson attempts to adjust to life after prison; she is fired from two jobs due to her criminal background, which drives her to return temporarily to drug dealing. During an interview about the book, she said, "Every time I turned around, they kept firing me, so where else could I turn to? The streets never let you down. That's sad to say, but what (was) I supposed to be, starving? Go to a shelter?"

Cryptanthus regius
Cryptanthus regius is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus sanctaluciae
Cryptanthus sanctaluciae is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus tiradentesensis
Cryptanthus tiradentesensis is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus warasii
Cryptanthus warasii is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus warren-loosei
Cryptanthus warren-loosei is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

You Wouldn't Know (Bee Gees song)
"You Wouldn't Know" is a song written by Barry Gibb which was recorded by the Bee Gees and released as the B-side of their version of "Every Day I Have to Cry" and later included on the album "The Bee Gees Sing and Play 14 Barry Gibb Songs" (1965). The album of the same name was released in Europe by Tring Records and features the Bee Gees songs from 1963-1966.

Gagea
Gagea is a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family. It is found primarily in Eurasia with a few species extending into North Africa and North America.

Lloydieae
The Lloydieae were a tribe of monocotyledon perennial, herbaceous mainly bulbous flowering plants in the Liliaceae (Lily) family. The tribe was generally considered monogeric, being represented by the single genus "Lloydia". But since that genus has at various times and is now considered to be part of the genus "Gagea", and therefore in the "Lilieae" tribe, it was sometimes listed with both genera. Furthermore many authorities place "Gagea" into a separate tribe, Tulipeae. It has also historically been considered to be a subtribe of the Lilieae. In 2013, Kim "et al." proposed splitting off "Gagea" from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae.

Here's the Thing
Here's the Thing is a public radio show and podcast interview series hosted by actor Alec Baldwin. On October 24, 2011, New York City's WNYC released the first episode of Baldwin's podcast, a series of interviews with public figures including artists, policy makers and performers. "Here's the Thing" was developed for Baldwin by Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathy Russo and Emily Botein.

Quesnelia
Quesnelia is a genus of the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. The genus is named For M. Quesnel, French consul to French Guiana. Endemic to eastern Brazil, this genus contains 22 known species. This genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Billbergiopsis" .

Rhodostemonodaphne
Rhodostemonodaphne is a genus of flowering plants in the family Lauraceae. It is a neotropical genus consisting of approximately 41 species occurring in Central America and northern South America. This genus has many species that are valued for timber. The classification of the genus is unclear since the species in the genus fall into a well-supported but unresolved clade that also includes species with unisexual flowers currently placed in the genera "Endlicheria" and part of "Ocotea".

Coleataenia
Coleataenia is a grass genus in the Paniceae tribe of the Poaceae. Until recently this genus was part of "Panicum". In 2010, Zuloaga, Scataglini, & Morrone proposed the transfer of the "Panicum" sections "Agrostoidea" and "Tenera" to the new genus, "Sorengia". However, that same year, because one of the new species' synonyms was in the valid "Coleataenia" genus, Robert J. Soreng determined that "Sorengia" was not a valid name for the new genus and re-published it as "Coleataenia".

Palerontobia
Palerontobia is a monotypic genus of tiger moths in the "Erebidae" family. The genus includes only one species, Palerontobia kozlovi, which is found in north-eastern Tibet (China, Qinghai). The scientific name consists of two parts, "Pale," is a part of the genus name "Palearctia", and "rontobia," is a part of the genus name "Orontobia". The species is named after Pyotr Kozlov, a disciple of Nikolay Przhevalsky, who first collected the Holotype in 1900.

The common name for any Cryptanthus is "Earth Star". Some species within this genus include Cryptanthus regius, Cryptanthus sanctaluciae, Cryptanthus tiradentesensis, Cryptanthus warasii, and Cryptanthus warren-loosei, all of which are also endemic to Brazil.

nodes.output: Gagea is a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family, primarily found in Eurasia with some species extending into North Africa and North America. It is also worth noting that the genus was historically considered to be part of the tribe Lloydieae, but in 2013, it was proposed to be split off from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae. nodes.instruction: Determine if Cryptanthus is classified as a genus based on the retrieved information.
nodes.output: Based on the information retrieved, Cryptanthus is classified as a genus within the Bromeliaceae family.

nodes.instruction: Determine if Gagea is classified as a genus based on the retrieved information.
nodes.output: Yes, Gagea is classified as a genus based on the information provided. It is described as a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family, with species primarily found in Eurasia, North Africa, and North America. Additionally, it was historically considered to be part of the tribe Lloydieae, and in 2013, it was proposed to be split off from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae, further solidifying its classification as a genus.

nodes.instruction: Based on the classifications from nodes 3 and 4, determine if both Cryptanthus and Gagea are genera.
nodes.output: Yes, both Cryptanthus and Gagea are genera based on the classifications from nodes 3 and 4.

The book also depicts the difficulty with which Pearson attempts to adjust to life after prison; she is fired from two jobs due to her criminal background, which drives her to return temporarily to drug dealing. During an interview about the book, she said, "Every time I turned around, they kept firing me, so where else could I turn to? The streets never let you down. That's sad to say, but what (was) I supposed to be, starving? Go to a shelter?"

Cryptanthus regius
Cryptanthus regius is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus sanctaluciae
Cryptanthus sanctaluciae is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus tiradentesensis
Cryptanthus tiradentesensis is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus warasii
Cryptanthus warasii is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

Cryptanthus warren-loosei
Cryptanthus warren-loosei is a species in the genus "Cryptanthus". This species is endemic to Brazil.

You Wouldn't Know (Bee Gees song)
"You Wouldn't Know" is a song written by Barry Gibb which was recorded by the Bee Gees and released as the B-side of their version of "Every Day I Have to Cry" and later included on the album "The Bee Gees Sing and Play 14 Barry Gibb Songs" (1965). The album of the same name was released in Europe by Tring Records and features the Bee Gees songs from 1963-1966.

Gagea
Gagea is a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family. It is found primarily in Eurasia with a few species extending into North Africa and North America.

Lloydieae
The Lloydieae were a tribe of monocotyledon perennial, herbaceous mainly bulbous flowering plants in the Liliaceae (Lily) family. The tribe was generally considered monogeric, being represented by the single genus "Lloydia". But since that genus has at various times and is now considered to be part of the genus "Gagea", and therefore in the "Lilieae" tribe, it was sometimes listed with both genera. Furthermore many authorities place "Gagea" into a separate tribe, Tulipeae. It has also historically been considered to be a subtribe of the Lilieae. In 2013, Kim "et al." proposed splitting off "Gagea" from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae.

Here's the Thing
Here's the Thing is a public radio show and podcast interview series hosted by actor Alec Baldwin. On October 24, 2011, New York City's WNYC released the first episode of Baldwin's podcast, a series of interviews with public figures including artists, policy makers and performers. "Here's the Thing" was developed for Baldwin by Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathy Russo and Emily Botein.

Quesnelia
Quesnelia is a genus of the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. The genus is named For M. Quesnel, French consul to French Guiana. Endemic to eastern Brazil, this genus contains 22 known species. This genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Billbergiopsis" .

Rhodostemonodaphne
Rhodostemonodaphne is a genus of flowering plants in the family Lauraceae. It is a neotropical genus consisting of approximately 41 species occurring in Central America and northern South America. This genus has many species that are valued for timber. The classification of the genus is unclear since the species in the genus fall into a well-supported but unresolved clade that also includes species with unisexual flowers currently placed in the genera "Endlicheria" and part of "Ocotea".

Coleataenia
Coleataenia is a grass genus in the Paniceae tribe of the Poaceae. Until recently this genus was part of "Panicum". In 2010, Zuloaga, Scataglini, & Morrone proposed the transfer of the "Panicum" sections "Agrostoidea" and "Tenera" to the new genus, "Sorengia". However, that same year, because one of the new species' synonyms was in the valid "Coleataenia" genus, Robert J. Soreng determined that "Sorengia" was not a valid name for the new genus and re-published it as "Coleataenia".

Palerontobia
Palerontobia is a monotypic genus of tiger moths in the "Erebidae" family. The genus includes only one species, Palerontobia kozlovi, which is found in north-eastern Tibet (China, Qinghai). The scientific name consists of two parts, "Pale," is a part of the genus name "Palearctia", and "rontobia," is a part of the genus name "Orontobia". The species is named after Pyotr Kozlov, a disciple of Nikolay Przhevalsky, who first collected the Holotype in 1900.

But since that genus has at various times and is now considered to be part of the genus "Gagea", and therefore in the "Lilieae" tribe, it was sometimes listed with both genera. Furthermore many authorities place "Gagea" into a separate tribe, Tulipeae. It has also historically been considered to be a subtribe of the Lilieae. In 2013, Kim "et al." proposed splitting off "Gagea" from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae.

Here's the Thing
Here's the Thing is a public radio show and podcast interview series hosted by actor Alec Baldwin. On October 24, 2011, New York City's WNYC released the first episode of Baldwin's podcast, a series of interviews with public figures including artists, policy makers and performers. "Here's the Thing" was developed for Baldwin by Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathy Russo and Emily Botein.

Quesnelia
Quesnelia is a genus of the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. The genus is named For M. Quesnel, French consul to French Guiana. Endemic to eastern Brazil, this genus contains 22 known species. This genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Billbergiopsis" .

Rhodostemonodaphne
Rhodostemonodaphne is a genus of flowering plants in the family Lauraceae. It is a neotropical genus consisting of approximately 41 species occurring in Central America and northern South America. This genus has many species that are valued for timber. The classification of the genus is unclear since the species in the genus fall into a well-supported but unresolved clade that also includes species with unisexual flowers currently placed in the genera "Endlicheria" and part of "Ocotea".

Coleataenia
Coleataenia is a grass genus in the Paniceae tribe of the Poaceae. Until recently this genus was part of "Panicum". In 2010, Zuloaga, Scataglini, & Morrone proposed the transfer of the "Panicum" sections "Agrostoidea" and "Tenera" to the new genus, "Sorengia". However, that same year, because one of the new species' synonyms was in the valid "Coleataenia" genus, Robert J. Soreng determined that "Sorengia" was not a valid name for the new genus and re-published it as "Coleataenia".

Palerontobia
Palerontobia is a monotypic genus of tiger moths in the "Erebidae" family. The genus includes only one species, Palerontobia kozlovi, which is found in north-eastern Tibet (China, Qinghai). The scientific name consists of two parts, "Pale," is a part of the genus name "Palearctia", and "rontobia," is a part of the genus name "Orontobia". The species is named after Pyotr Kozlov, a disciple of Nikolay Przhevalsky, who first collected the Holotype in 1900.

nodes.output: The genus Cryptanthus is a part of the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. It has two recognized subgenera and all species are endemic to Brazil. The common name for any Cryptanthus is "Earth Star". Some species within this genus include Cryptanthus regius, Cryptanthus sanctaluciae, Cryptanthus tiradentesensis, Cryptanthus warasii, and Cryptanthus warren-loosei, all of which are also endemic to Brazil.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about the genus Gagea.
nodes.output: Gagea is a large genus of spring flowers in the lily family, primarily found in Eurasia with some species extending into North Africa and North America. It is also worth noting that the genus Lloydieae was historically considered part of the Gagea genus, and in 2013, it was proposed to split off Gagea from the rest of Tulipeae by resurrecting the tribe Lloydieae. This information provides an overview of the Gagea genus and its historical classification within the plant taxonomy.

retrieved_passages:
Cryptanthus
Cryptanthus is a genus in the botanical family Bromeliaceae, subfamily Bromelioideae. The genus name is from the Greek “cryptos” (hidden) and “anthos” (flower). This genus has two recognized subgenera: the type subgenus and "Hoplocryptanthus" . All species of this genus are endemic to Brazil. The common name for any "Cryptanthus" is "Earth Star".

Grace After Midnight
According to the memoir, Pearson says her life was turned around upon learning in prison that a close friend and drug dealer, whom she called "Uncle", was killed. Pearson said of her decision to write her book, "I just want to let people know where I came from ... to share my story. I know the Lord has blessed me. He gave me the power just to tell this story." The book also depicts the difficulty with which Pearson attempts to adjust to life after prison; she is fired from two jobs due to her criminal background, which drives her to return temporarily to drug dealing. During an interview about the book, she said, "Every time I turned around, they kept firing me, so where else could I turn to? The streets never let you down. That's sad to say, but what (was) I supposed to be, starving? Go to a shelter?"

The album of the same name was released in Europe by Tring Records and features the Bee Gees songs from 1963-1966.
